docs.lead_paragraph: The authorities in the Baltic port of Wladyslawowo levied a $3,000 fine on a visiting Dutch ship carrying a mobile abortion clinic. The harbor master said the boat had failed to obey his orders to tie up away from antiabortion demonstrators who pelted the boat with rocks and paint on Sunday. The boat, organized by the Dutch abortion rights group Women on Waves, has stirred a controversy since it came to bring birth control and pregnancy counseling to the Roman Catholic country, where abortion is outlawed. Women on Waves has said that it will take women seeking abortions into international waters and administer abortion-inducing drugs. On Monday, customs officials sealed the boat's supply of pills. Peter S. Green (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Abortion Boat Fined

docs.abstract: Mobile abortion clinic housed on Dutch ship and organized by Women on Waves, women's rights group, is fined $3,000 by Wladyslawowo (Poland) port authorities for failing to follow docking instructions that required ship to tie up away from protesters; boat brings birth control and pregnancy counseling to countries where abortion is illegal; boards women wanting abortions and takes them to international waters to perform procedure (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The city medical examiner has ruled that the death of an infant born on April 4 in a bathroom at Cardinal Spellman High School in the Bronx was a homicide, the police said yesterday. The determination -- which means that the death was the result of an action taken by another person -- does not place blame, however.

headline.main: Death of Newborn Is Ruled a Homicide

docs.abstract: Death of infant born in bathroom at Cardinal Spellman High School in New York City is ruled homicide; 16-year-old mother has not been arrested (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Ina May's Guide to Childbirth,'' by Ina May Gaskin. Bantam Books, $14.95. ''The Pregnancy Journal,'' by Dr. A. Christine Harris. Chronicle Books, $18.95. Each woman responds to giving birth in her unique way, writes the renowned midwife Ina May Gaskin in her celebration of the process of childbirth, ''and how very wide-ranging that way can be.'' Her book is a combination of advice on how to have a healthy, joyful childbirth, and of inspirational birthing stories.

headline.main: Pregnancy and Childbirth: More Than How-To Guides

docs.abstract: Midwife Ina May's Guide to Childbirth is her celebration of birth process, inspired by work at Farm Midwifery Center in Summertown, Tennessee; recognizes power of women in childbirth without technological influence; Dr A Christine Harris book Pregnancy Journal gives day-to-day guide for mothers-to-be; chronicles fetal milestones and gives helpful advice for mothers during pregnancy and after baby is born; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For two days last week, the Langenort, a Dutch-registered tugboat, was kept at sea by bad weather off the Baltic coast of Poland. On Saturday, as the winds fell, it was the shipping container bolted to its deck that kept the boat from harbor in Gdansk. The off-white container holds a mobile abortion clinic, and in Catholic Poland, where abortion is outlawed, its presence is unwelcome by many.

headline.main: A Rocky Polish Landfall For a Dutch Abortion Boat

docs.abstract: Langenort, Dutch-registered ship run by Women on Waves, docks in Wladyslawowo, Poland, where it intends to receive Polish women who are in first month and a half of their pregnancies and take them to international waters for abortions; small crowd of protesters pelts ship with paint bombs and stones; current Polish law allows abortion only if mother's life is in danger, or if she was raped or if baby has certain grave genetic defects; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was the pain in her feet that finally persuaded Vicki Daly Redholtz to seek help 12 years ago. The combination of shooting pains and numbness intensified at night, Ms. Redholtz, a 58-year-old travel consultant in Culver City, Calif., recalled. She began by consulting a podiatrist, who sent her for numerous tests over several months, but her condition was not diagnosed until an alert technician recognized her symptoms: Type 2 diabetes. Looking back, Ms. Redholtz realizes now that she had exhibited many of the classic warning signs of Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the disease, for a long while. At the time she received the diagnosis, she was 46 years old, about 25 pounds overweight and had a strong family history of diabetes. For several years before the diagnosis was made, she had been unusually thirsty and seemed to be constantly going to the bathroom.

headline.main: With the Increase in Type 2 Diabetes Comes a Focus on Its Warning Signs

docs.lead_paragraph: ''BREAST is best'' -- that is what health care providers and advocates tell mothers who are making decisions about how to feed their newborns. What is usually meant by that statement is this: compared with bottle feeding, breast-feeding offers incomparable benefits to children, even to those fed that way for a relatively short time. Among the benefits are reduced risks of asthma, lymphoma, sudden infant death syndrome, meningitis, pneumonia, inflammatory bowel disease, allergies, infections, diarrhea and colds. In a majority of studies, breast-fed children have I.Q.'s 3 to 10 points higher than children who are nursed by the bottle.

headline.main: Babies Aren't the Only Beneficiaries of Breast-Feeding

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 60 percent of New York school districts violate state or city rules regulating the way students learn about drug abuse, AIDS and sex education, according to a study of the city school system's health programs for kindergarten through eighth grade. The study, conducted by Assemblyman Scott M. Stringer, a Manhattan Democrat, was based on two months of interviews with 27 of the city's 32 district health coordinators. According to the study, schools lack trained health teachers, use outdated textbooks and curriculum, and in some cases, do not even offer health classes.

headline.main: Assemblyman's Study Faults Health Education in Schools

docs.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA DeMuria, who is 14 years old and lives in suburban New Jersey, tuned in after the kids at school started to talk. She remembers her first episode, in which the sexually insatiable Samantha begins dating another woman. ''And I was like, 'Mom, you won't believe this.' '' Meanwhile, in Austin, Tex., 18-year-old Rachel Foster has held a viewing party at her house every Sunday night for the last two years. There are a few ground rules: all cell phones off, and no talking. ''It's like a church in there,'' says Stephanie Mansour, 17.
docs.abstract: Sarah Hepola article on popularity of HBO series Sex and the City, which begins its sixth and final season, focuses on its appeal to teen-age girls; photos (M)
